questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of weakness, weight loss, diarrhea, oily stools, and joint pain for about 6 months.  A diagnosis of malabsorption syndrome was suspected. A duodenal biopsy was done, and the findings are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, weight loss, and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems, or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR, which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

The treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months. Prolonged antibiotics are recommended, but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Other options:

Option B: Celiac disease presents as a malabsorption syndrome due to the immune response to gluten in the diet. It is characterized by the presence of IgA antigliadin, anti-endomysial, and anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Histology will show a flat appearance of the intestine epithelium with crypt hyperplasia and villous atrophy. There is also an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes and increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria. The image below shows the intestinal biopsy of a patient with celiac disease.

Option C: Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. It is predominantly seen in some tropical countries such as India. It is usually preceded by an episode of acute gastroenteritis. Small bowel biopsy resembles that of celiac disease. Treatment is with broad-spectrum antibiotics and folic acid.

Option D: Bacterial overgrowth causes deconjugation of bile acids and their deficiency in the lumen of the small intestine. This causes malabsorption, leading to diarrhea with steatorrhea.

questions.text: An obese and intellectually impaired patient whose hands are shown in the image below is brought by his relatives to the OPD. Blood investigations show low calcium, high phosphorous, and parathormone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing short metacarpals (brachydactyly) and the accompanying clinical scenario of obesity and intellectual disability with low calcium, high phosphorous, and high parathormone levels are suggestive of pseudohypoparathyroidism.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is an inherited disorder that is characterized by hypocalcemia and characteristic skeletal features, known as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). It is due to the loss of function mutation in genes encoding the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G-protein Gsα. This blocks the action of PTH, leading to reduced serum calcium and increased serum phosphate. AHO features include short stature, short metacarpals and metatarsals (brachydactyly), round facies, intellectual impairment, and heterotropic calcifications.

Although serum calcium is low and serum phosphate is high (like hypoparathyroidism), PTH levels are also found to be elevated, and thus this disorder is termed pseudohypoparathyroidism. Urinary cAMP excretion is low because PTH is unable to act on its downstream pathways.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin D deficiency occurs due to inadequate intake of dairy products rich in vitamin D, lack of vitamin supplementation, and decreased sunlight exposure. It results in a mild decrease in calcium levels, elevated parathormone levels due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, and low phosphate levels.

Option B: Hypoparathyroidism is due to the decreased production of parathormone from the parathyroid glands. It is characterized by low calcium and low parathormone levels with elevated phosphate. Clinical features of hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism include paresthesias, seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval.

Option D: Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism is also associated with AHO features. However, serum calcium, phosphate, and PTH levels are normal in these patients. Urinary cAMP is also normal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient with a history of recurrent arthritis presents with the deformity as shown below. No joint erosions are seen on the radiograph. Investigations show negative anti-CCP antibodies and the presence of nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a deformity with ulnar deviation of the fingers. The absence of anti-CCP antibodies rules out Rheumatoid Arthritis. Non-erosive arthritis and nephrotic range proteinuria point towards SLE.

Patients with SLE tend to have intermittent polyarthritis, most commonly involving hands, wrists, and knees. Along with arthritis, there is inflammation of the surrounding soft tissues as well. Erosions are rarely seen. Joint deformities such as swan neck and ulnar deviation of the fingers can develop, but they are often reducible — unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these deformities are not reducible. Ischemic necrosis of the bone is seen more commonly in SLE than in rheumatoid arthritis, and the diagnosis should be suspected when pain persists in a single joint.

Renal involvement in SLE is known as lupus nephritis. Immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as a full-house effect. Electron microscopy will show the presence of subendothelial deposits.

Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and psoriatic arthritis cause joint erosions. Furthermore, proteinuria is not a likely manifestation in psoriatic arthritis and osteoarthritis, but can be present in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents with sudden onset spastic weakness of the right leg. He also has urinary incontinence. There are no speech abnormalities. Which of the following arteries is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of spastic weakness in the right leg along with urinary incontinence (suggesting involvement of paracentral lobule) suggests an occlusion of the left anterior cerebral artery. 

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is divided into two segments. A1 segment lies proximal to the anterior communicating artery and connects internal carotid artery with the anterior communicating artery. The portion of ACA which lies distal to anterior communicating artery is termed as A2 segment. 

Any occlusion in the A1 segment is tolerated well because of collateral blood circulation. But occlusion of the A2 segment of ACA gives rise to:

  • Paralysis of the opposite leg and foot
  • Paresis of the opposite arm (to a lesser extent)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to involvement of paracentral lobule)
  • Abulia, slowness, lack of spontaneity
  • Impairment of gait

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of palpitations. He is hemodynamically stable. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows wide complex tachycardia (QRS complexes are >120 ms in duration), with regular QRS complexes with uniform morphology in each lead. This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Since this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best management is IV amiodarone. 

In patients with sustained VT who are hemodynamically stable, medical treatment with intravenous amiodarone is preferred. Alternative drugs that can be given are lignocaine and procainamide. However, if the VT fails to resolve with medical management or if the patient's symptoms worsen, DC cardioversion is the next step. 

Other options:

Option A: Carotid massage has no role in the management of VT. It is used as an initial step in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to block the AV node and terminate the arrhythmia.

Option B: Chest compressions are done until the defibrillator is arranged to ensure some amount of cardiac output even during this period.

Option C: If a patient with VT has hemodynamic compromise due to hypotension or impaired consciousness or has pulmonary, electrical cardioversion is performed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with a loss of libido for the past year. He was also diagnosed with diabetes 6 months ago, and has recently developed arthritis in his fingers. On examination, he has skin pigmentation and testicular atrophy. Serum ferritin is elevated. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given patient has loss of libido and testicular atrophy, along with the characteristic triad of skin pigmentation, arthritis, and diabetes, suggesting a diagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis. Elevated serum ferritin supports this diagnosis.

Hereditary hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene, present on chromosome 6p. This mutation causes a decreased synthesis of hepcidin. This in turn causes unchecked iron absorption from the intestinal mucosa, leading to iron overload. Liver is the organ that is affected first and most severely.

Patients present with hepatomegaly and characteristic bronze skin pigmentation due to excess melanin and iron deposition in the skin. Diabetes mellitus and arthropathy involving the joints of the hand, especially the metacarpal joints, are also seen.

Asymptomatic and symptomatic family members of the patients should be screened with serum ferritin and percentage transferrin saturation. In the early phase of hemochromatosis, these values will be found to be elevated even before the iron stores are significantly increased in the liver. If serum ferritin and/or transferrin saturation are found to be elevated, the next step is to test the individual for HFE genotype to decide the further management.

Iron removal from the body is best achieved by periodic phlebotomy. Chelating agents such as deferoxamine are indicated when co-morbidities such as anemia and hypoproteinemia prevent the use of phlebotomy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient working in the cement manufacturing industry presents with chronic cough and dyspnea. His chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic cough and dyspnea with the chest radiograph showing eggshell calcification of the hilar lymph nodes, a diagnosis of silicosis is the most likely.

Silicosis is the most common occupational lung disease in the world. Occupational exposures associated with silicosis include mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying of granite. The pathogenic form of silica is crystalline quartz. Inhaled silica crystals are phagocytosed by macrophages and cause the release of IL-1 and IL-18. This causes the recruitment of more inflammatory cells and fibroblasts to the site, leading to collagen deposition.

Silicosis can present in the following ways:

  • Acute silicosis occurs due to exposure to high concentrations of silica in closed spaces. Patients have clinical manifestations within a few months to years of exposure.
  • Chronic silicosis occurs due to long-term exposure to silica, often 10 to 30 years
  • Progressive massive fibrosis can occur following both acute and chronic silicosis. The patients present with more severe cough and dyspnea than simple silicosis, and might develop respiratory failure and cor pulmonale. 

Since silicosis leads to macrophage dysfunction, it increases the risk of tuberculosis in patients. Silica also has immunoadjuvant properties, and might lead to autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. Silica exposure is also considered to be a risk factor for lung cancer.

Calcification of hilar lymph nodes producing a characteristic eggshell pattern is seen in many cases of silicosis. The fibrotic areas present in the lung parenchyma can be identified on the HRCT of the lung. Acute silicosis may show diffuse ground-glass opacities with thickening of the interlobular septae, which is termed as crazy pavement appearance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old asthma patient complains of a cough with brownish expectoration. He is not responding to his usual therapy for asthma. He has elevated circulating levels of IgE and prominent peripheral eosinophilia. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of asthma in this patient, along with cough with brownish expectoration and elevated circulating IgE and eosinophilia, and a chest radiograph showing the characteristic finger-in-glove sign, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to colonisation of the airways by Aspergillus fumigatus. The risk factors predisposing to ABPA include asthma and cystic fibrosis. There is an obstruction of the bronchioles due to the inflammatory secretions, leading to breathlessness, coughing, and brown sputum casts.

The total circulating IgE and Aspergillus-specific IgE is elevated, and there is peripheral eosinophilia. Chest radiographs may show central bronchiectasis and finger-in-glove signs due to mucous impaction in the airways. The treatment of ABPA is with itraconazole and glucocorticoids.

Other options: 

Option B: Loffler syndrome refers to transient pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia that occur in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs, most commonly larvae of Ascaris species.

Option C: Bronchiectasis is characterised by irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles. Patients have recurrent episodes of cough with copious amounts of sputum, often foul-smelling. Radiographic features include:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest radiograph
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen
  • A signet ring sign is seen when the diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery in a cross-section, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs due to the inflammatory response to the microfilariae. The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheezing and cough.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER with breathlessness and hypotension. On examination, there were soft heart sounds and JVP was elevated. A transthoracic echocardiography revealed an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. Which of the following can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space suggests pericardial tamponade. Electrical alternans is seen in pericardial tamponade.

In tamponade, the ventricular filling is limited because ventricles cannot expand into the fluid-filled pericardial cavity. This leads to a reduction in cardiac output and arterial pressure as well. The three cardinal features of tamponade are given by Beck's triad, and include hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and distension of the jugular veins.

There is a prominent x descent in JVP but absent y descent. Paradoxical pulse, which refers to a drop of SBP >10 mmHg during inspiration, is also seen in tamponade. Although more likely to indicate tamponade, paradoxical pulse can also be seen in constrictive pericarditis and chronic obstructive airway disease. ECG in tamponade shows electrical alternans, which refers to alternating QRS amplitudes as shown in the ECG given below.

 

On the other hand, the main abnormality which occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent (option A) in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling due to pericardial knock (option D) and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration, known as Kussmaul's sign (option C). The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. He is a known case of CKD on treatment with enalapril. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows peaked T waves, flattened P waves, and broad QRS complexes, suggesting hyperkalemia. This patient also has chronic kidney disease and is on treatment with an ACE inhibitor, enalapril. Both of these factors are independent risk factors for hyperkalemia. The first step in the management of hyperkalemia is the administration of IV calcium gluconate.

ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia vary with the level of serum K+ (normal serum K+ is 3.5-5.5 mEq/L):

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L- tall, peaked T waves
  • 6.5-7.5 mEq/L- flattening of P waves
  • 7.0-8.0 mEq/L - widening of QRS complexes
  • >8.0 mEq/L - sine wave pattern of ECG

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Early loss of procedural memory is not a feature of Alzheimer's disease.

Alzheimer's disease is a syndrome of acquired global or multifocal impairment of cognitive function involving a decline of intellect, memory, or personality in the presence of normal consciousness.

Risk factors:

  • Old age
  • ApoE ε4 allele
  • Less education
  • Diabetes
  • Positive family history
  • Head trauma 
  • Female sex
  • Viruses, prion

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with the following finding. His oxygen saturation is 80% despite a good respiratory effort, a clear airway, and bilateral breath sounds. Oxygen administration via nasal cannula did not improve oxygen saturation. Methemoglobinemia was suspected. Which of the following should be given in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
The given image showing cyanosis (bluish lips), along with a history of decreased oxygen saturation, supports the suspicion of methemoglobinemia. IV methylene blue is the preferred treatment.

Normally the iron in hemoglobin is stored in ferrous (Fe2+) state. When this iron is in oxidized form (Fe3+), the hemoglobin is called methemoglobin. Methemoglobin does not bind to oxygen readily, and is not able to deliver the oxygen to the peripheral tissues. This causes tissue hypoxia and leftward shifting of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

Acquired methemoglobinemia can occur due to a number of drugs, such as nitrites (option B) dapsone, local anesthetics such as benzocaine, and antimalarials such as chloroquine and primaquine (option D). It presents as cyanosis that does not respond to oxygen administration. Therefore, oxygen administration via face mask (option A) would not help in this patient. Methemoglobin assay is used to determine the exact levels of methemoglobin in the blood. Patients are treated with IV methylene blue or vitamin C administration.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with serous otitis media of the left ear and a history of bloody nasal discharge and hemoptysis. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and the urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria. Investigations show elevated ESR and positive ANCA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings point to a diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Wegener's granulomatosis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels with the formation of granulomas at multiple sites. The classic feature of this disease is the involvement of the triad of upper and lower respiratory tracts, and the kidneys.

Patients present with paranasal sinus pain and discharge (purulent or bloody) and may end up developing nasal septal perforation and saddle nose deformity. Eustachian tube block can lead to otitis media with effusion and conductive hearing loss. Lower respiratory tract involvement presents as cough and hemoptysis due to multiple, bilateral cavitary infiltrates in the lungs. Renal pathology typically evolves quickly into rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. It is important to note that there is no granuloma formation in the kidney and there is no immune complex deposition either.

Laboratory findings show elevated levels of c-ANCA (antiproteinase-3 ANCA), ESR, CRP, and RA factor. The diagnosis can be established by demonstration of necrotizing granulomatous inflammation on tissue biopsy in a suspected patient. The presence of ANCA antibodies is adjunct as they may be absent in some patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to result as a complication of chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
CKD is typically associated with anemia due to associated low erythropoietin levels, not polycythemia.

The complications associated with CKD and the measures used to treat them are given below:

  • Antihypertensive therapy slows the progression of CKD, irrespective of the drug that is used. However, the use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs for this purpose has the added benefit of reducing proteinuria. Reduction in proteinuria also reduces the risk of progression.
  • Patients should be advised to limit their potassium intake by reducing foods with high potassium such as bananas. Potassium-binding resins such as patiromer can also be used.
  • Sodium bicarbonate supplementation may be indicated in patients who have chronic high-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Active vitamin D metabolites such as calcitriol should be given to patients with renal bone disease.
  • Hyperphosphatemia is treated with restriction of high phosphate foods such as milk and eggs, and with phosphate binders such as lanthanum and sevelamer.
  • Anemia associated with CKD is treated with darbepoetin after replenishing the iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12 stores of the body.

questions.text: An elderly woman who underwent a hip replacement surgery 1 week back now complains of hemoptysis and breathlessness. On examination, she complains of pain in her calf on pressing it, and her heart rate is 120 beats per minute. The D-dimer levels are found to be elevated. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of deep vein thrombosis, breathlessness, and hemoptysis after major surgery with elevated levels of D-dimer suggest that the patient has a pulmonary embolism. The next step in the management of this patient is to perform a CT pulmonary angiography.

Approach to a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) should be suspected in a patient who complains of sudden breathlessness and hemoptysis after prolonged immobilization. Well's point score helps to estimate the clinical likelihood of PE. When patients' chances of PE are high, the patient should be assessed for D-dimer levels. Normal levels of D-dimer rule out the possibility of PE. If the D-dimer levels are elevated, then the chances of pulmonary embolism are very high and the patient should undergo imaging to confirm the diagnosis.

CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It can provide exquisite detail, with ≤1 mm of resolution during a short breath-hold. It also helps to visualize the chambers of the heart. In patients who do not have a pulmonary embolism, it can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.

Because of the invasive nature of pulmonary angiography (option B) and availability of chest CT scans, it is not commonly used in the diagnosis of PE. It is reserved for patients with technically unsatisfactory chest CTs and for those for whom an interventional procedure such as catheter-directed thrombolysis is planned.

Lung scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Small particulate aggregates of albumin labeled with a gamma-emitting radionuclide are injected intravenously and are trapped in the pulmonary capillary bed. The perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

MR pulmonary angiography is a reliable test to identify deep vein thrombosis. It may detect large proximal PE, but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE.

Most patients with PE have a normal echocardiogram (option D). Therefore, it is not a reliable test to detect PE. However, it can be used to detect other conditions that commonly mimic PE like acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include:

  2. Heart rate <100 bpm

  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of fatigue. She is noted to have pallor. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows HbA of 91%, HbA2 of 8%, and HbF of 1%. Peripheral smear shows findings as below. RDW is normal. Which of the following is likely to be true for this patient's condition?

RDW - Red cell distribution width
questions.solution:
This patient with pallor, microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells on peripheral smear, haemoglobin electrophoresis revealing elevated HbA2 (normal: 2.2 to 2.8%), and a normal RDW is likely to have a beta-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia occurs due to disorders in globin synthesis. 

Thalassemia occurs due to mutations in globin gene expression. The mutations can affect the alpha and beta subunits, leading to variable presentation and severity depending on which gene is affected.

Patients with β thalassemia major present with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. Marrow hyperplasia in the skill can lead to prominence of cheekbones and other bony prominences (chipmunk facies) and crewcut appearance, as shown below. 

These patients require regular blood transfusions and are at risk of developing secondary hemochromatosis. Iron chelators are given to prevent this. However, the prognosis is guarded, and the only curative treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Patients with β thalassemia minor are mostly asymptomatic or may have mild anemia.

A complete blood count will show low hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume (MCV), indicating microcytic hypochromic anemia. Mentzer index (MCV/red cell count) will be less than 13. The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic cells, anisopoikilocytosis, increased reticulocyte count, and target cells. 

Iron studies are performed to differentiate between thalassemia and iron deficiency anemia. Thalassemia has normal or increased serum iron and transferrin saturation. Iron deficiency anemia has decreased serum iron and transferrin saturation. Red cell distribution width (RDW) is generally normal in thalassemia and increased in iron deficiency. 

Hemoglobin electrophoresis measures the type of hemoglobin present in cells. Normally, Hemoglobin A (HbA) is 95-98%, Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2) is 2-3%, and Hemoglobin F (HbF) is less than 2%. Patients with β thalassemia minor usually have HbA2 between 4-8%, HbA >90%, and a small amount of HbF. Patients with transfusion-dependent β thalassemia have <5% HbA1, while HbF is 90-100%. 

Other options:

Option A: A low transferrin saturation is seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Option C: Mentzer index of more than 13 is seen in iron deficiency anemia. 

Option D: Bite cells are seen in the peripheral smear of patients with glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase(G6PD) deficiency.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text:
An elderly lady presented with weight gain. On examination, her limbs appeared thin, and her blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg. She is also noticed to have the following findings, as shown in the image below. Her lab investigation findings are given below. This condition is likely to be due to
  • 24h urinary free cortisol- elevated 
  • Plasma cortisol after administration of 1mg dexamethasone - elevated
  • Plasma ACTH levels- elevated
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone test- negative
  • High-dose dexamethasone test- negative
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing buffalo hump, central obesity, and purple stretch marks, is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. It is likely to be due to ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production.

Cushing's syndrome refers to a group of clinical features that result from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It can be ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the increased glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
  • Hypertension
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Lymphopenia
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression
  • Psychosis 
  • Anxiety

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Cushing's syndrome.

Once Cushing's syndrome is suspected, laboratory investigations are useful in the diagnosis. Patients will have elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol levels; they have elevated levels of plasma cortisol, which are not suppressed by dexamethasone. If these are elevated, it confirms that the patient has elevated levels of cortisol.

The next step is to evaluate if the elevated cortisol levels are due to elevated ACTH or are independent of ACTH levels. In this patient, the ACTH levels are elevated, which means that increased ACTH has caused increased production of cortisol. Increased ACTH can be due to a pituitary tumor that produces ACTH or ectopic ACTH production that is seen in tumors like bronchial or pancreatic carcinoids, medullary thyroid carcinoma, etc.

The source of ACTH production can be identified using an MRI of the pituitary, a corticotropin-releasing hormone test, and a high-dose dexamethasone test. If the ACTH production is due to an adenoma in the pituitary, it responds to the administration of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and is suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone. In this patient, both of these tests are negative, which means that ACTH production is not from the pituitary but is due to ectopic production of ACTH. The patient has to be evaluated for underlying tumours. 

Other options:

Option A: Pituitary adenoma has elevated levels of cortisol and is normal to high ACTH levels. The pituitary MRI might show the presence of a tumor. CRH test and high-dose dexamethasone tests are positive.

Option B: In bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, there are increased levels of cortisol. However, the ACTH levels are low due to negative feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary.

Option C: In adrenocortical adenoma also, cortisol levels are associated with a decrease in ACTH levels.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: A young patient with asthma currently not on any treatment reports that he experiences symptoms once a week and no nighttime awakenings. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment strategy for him?

choices.text: Inhaled corticosteroids plus formoterol when needed

questions.solution:
Presence of daytime symptoms only once a week and the absence of any nighttime symptoms points to a diagnosis of intermittent asthma in this patient. The most appropriate treatment strategy for him would be inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and formoterol when needed. 

Patients with intermittent asthma were treated with a short-acting β2-receptor agonist such as salbutamol as a reliever medication. However, chronic airway inflammation is present even in patients with intermittent asthma and can lead to more severe attacks in the future. To tackle this, GINA now recommends the use of low-dose ICS and formoterol combination inhaler when needed even in patients with intermittent asthma. Even though formoterol is a long-acting β2-receptor agonist, its onset of action is quick and it provides quick symptom relief to the patient.

Asthma is categorized as intermittent if the patient has daytime symptoms up to 2 times per week, and nighttime awakenings due to symptoms up to 2 times per month. If the symptoms are more severe than this, then the patient's asthma is categorized to be persistent. Persistent asthma is further divided into the following based on the severity of the symptoms:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes with complaints of drooping eyelids and double vision in both eyes, The symptoms worsen with repetitive eye movements and resolve after rest. Chest radiography revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following is not a feature of her condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of intermittent complaints of ptosis and weakness of extraocular muscles (causing diplopia), which worsen after repetitive eye movements, is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Chest radiography showing an anterior mediastinal mass (most likely a thymoma) supports this diagnosis. Deep tendon reflexes are normal in myasthenia gravis, not absent.

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest or chest radiography.

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. Weakness of the muscles of the face (option C), palate and tongue may lead to difficulty in swallowing (option D). When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs (option A) are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

  • Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay
  • Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response
  • Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG
  • Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
  • Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

  • Presence of thymoma
  • Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features are seen in Parkinson's disease?
  1. Anosmia
  2. Intention tremor
  3. Visual hallucinations
  4. Asymmetrical rigidity
  5. Bradykinesia
questions.solution:
Parkinson's disease (PD) is characterized by anosmia, peripheral rigidity, and bradykinesia out of the given statements.

PD is characterized by the following four cardinal motor features. Note that Parkinsonism is a broad term that is used when bradykinesia, rigidity and/or tremor are present together. 

  1. Resting tremor 
  2. Asymmetrical rigidity (statement 4)
  3. Bradykinesia (statement 5)
  4. Dysfunction of the gait and postural instability

Cerebellar lesions are characterized by an action tremor that becomes worse as the patient's hand approaches the target. This gives rise to the term intention tremor (statement 2). It is not seen in PD. 

Although atypical parkinsonism syndromes (such as multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and corticobasal degeneration) also present with features of parkinsonism, they differ from PD in that they have a more aggressive course, the motor symptoms symmetrically involve both halves of the body, and tremors are usually absent.

The non-motor manifestations of PD include:

  • Anosmia (statement 1)
  • Sensory symptoms such as pain
  • Mood disorders such as depression
  • Sleep disturbances
  • Autonomic issues: orthostatic hypotension, GI disturbances, sexual dysfunction
  • Dementia

In a patient with parkinsonian features, the presence of visual hallucinations (statement 3) points to a diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB). DLB is characterized by the emergence of neuropsychiatric manifestations before or at the same time as motor manifestations. However, in Parkinson's disease dementia, the cognitive decline occurs many years after the motor symptoms have appeared.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient complains of episodic pain on the left side of her face. The pain is triggered when she is chewing or washing her face and lasts for about a minute. There is no sensory loss or autonomic dysfunction. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged female with paroxysmal pain in the face, which is triggered by movements and washing of the face, is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. 

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, and smiling. Certain trigger zones are present on the face which provoke these attacks. Tactile stimuli such as washing the face and brushing teeth may trigger the pain. The pain usually lasts for a few seconds to 1-2 minutes.

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face but do not carry the pain sensation. In trigeminal neuralgia, compression of the large fibers leads to their demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones leads to pain paroxysms.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, phenytoin, topiramate, or gabapentin are other options that may be tried if carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Other options:

Options A, B: Cluster headache and SUNCT are examples of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias. Both of them are characterized by a stabbing type of pain in the periorbital region, along with autonomic features such as lacrimation and conjunctival tearing on the ipsilateral side and nasal stuffiness. Since this patient has no autonomic features, both of these options can be ruled out.

Option D: Temporal arteritis is usually accompanied by manifestations in other systems (such as myalgias) and signs of inflammation (such as raised ESR and CRP). The patient might also have visual disturbances which can lead to permanent blindness. Furthermore, the pain is usually constant and does not have triggers as in the case of trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis is to be started on hydroxychloroquine. Which of the following would you advise him prior to starting this drug?
questions.solution:
Prior to starting hydroxychloroquine therapy for rheumatoid arthritis, the patient should be advised to undergo an ocular examination.

Hydroxychloroquine is a disease-modifying drug used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Both chloroquine and its derivative hydroxychloroquine are melanotropic. They get concentrated in the melanin-containing structures of the eye, such as the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and choroid. Significant retinal damage and visual deficits can develop in these patients, sometimes even without any signs on fundus examination. Therefore, baseline visual acuity testing and ocular examination are mandatory before starting hydroxychloroquine for a long duration.

As the retinopathy progresses, it leads to the formation of a bull's eye lesion, as shown in the picture below. It is characterized by pigment deposition in the foveola, surrounded by a ring of depigmented and atrophic RPE. This is further encircled by a hyperpigmented ring.

DMARDs that require tuberculosis screening (option B) include:

  • TNF-α inhibitors such as infliximab, etanercept, and adalimumab
  • JAK inhibitors such as tofacitinib and baricitinib
  • Interleukin-6 inhibitors such as tocilizumab
  • Anakinra
  • Abatacept

DMARDs that require evaluation for viral hepatitis include:

  • Leflunomide 
  • Methotrexate
  • Rituximab

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought to the hospital with complaints of palpitations and dizziness. His vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). In this patient, the next step would be the administration of IV adenosine.

PSVT is an arrhythmia characterized by a sudden onset and offset with rapid ventricular response. It includes atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia, junctional tachycardia, and AV reentry tachycardia.

Initial management of PSVT is by vagal maneuvers such as carotid massage, Valsalva maneuver, and breathing against pressure in a syringe. Vagal maneuvers increase the parasympathetic discharge, thus slowing down the conduction through the AV node and terminating the arrhythmia. Carotid sinus massage is avoided if the patient has a carotid bruit. 

If this method is ineffective, intravenous adenosine is used. It can terminate the majority of PSVT episodes by blocking the conduction at the AV node. If adenosine is also ineffective in terminating the arrhythmia, IV β blockers (esmolol, metoprolol) and IV non-DHP calcium channel blockers (verapamil and diltiazem) are used. Note that IV adenosine (option B) is preferred over β blockers and non-DHP CCBs (options A and D) for terminating PSVT because of its rapid onset, excellent success rate, and minimal negative inotropic effect.

Electrical cardioversion (option C) is done if the patient is hemodynamically unstable or if PSVT does not respond to any of the other methods mentioned above.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of low-grade fever, irritability, headache, and neck rigidity for the past 1 week. Examination reveals papilledema and abducens nerve palsy. MRI shows dilated ventricles and significant basal exudates. Which of the following would most likely be seen in the CSF?
questions.solution:
The features and imaging findings are suggestive of tuberculous meningitis. CSF analysis would most likely show lymphocytosis, low glucose level, and high protein level. 

Tuberculous meningitis presents as a subacute infection and has a longer course than bacterial meningitis. Ocular nerve palsy is a common association as there is marked meningeal involvement at the base of the brain. The patient can also develop hydrocephalus.

The clinical triad of fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity is common to all types of meningitis. Nuchal rigidity is the resistance of the neck to passive flexion and is pathognomonic of meningeal irritation. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs are other features of meningeal irritation. Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) is a complication that presents as papilledema, disorientation, or dilated poorly reactive pupils.

If the CSF is allowed to stand, a 'spider’s web clot' or 'cobweb' coagulum may form due to the high level of protein. There is usually lymphocytic leukocytosis, low glucose concentration, and elevated levels of proteins. Acid-fast bacilli are not frequently seen on the direct smear of the CSF sediment. CSF culture remains the gold standard for diagnosis. However, CB-NAAT (a type of nucleic acid amplification method) is the initial diagnostic test of choice because of its high sensitivity and quicker results compared to culture.

Imaging studies (CT and MRI) may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman diagnosed with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) 14 years back presents with breathlessness for a few months. Her PFT is as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis and the PFT showing an isolated decrease in DLCO suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH).

A PFT pattern showing near-normal FVC, increased FEV1, and decreased DLCO which is consistent with diffusion lung disease. The cause of diffusion lung disease can be due to both pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung disease (ILD). But in this patient with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, pulmonary artery hypertension is the most likely etiologic factor.

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is more strongly associated with the development of PAH than diffuse systemic sclerosis. However, diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis is associated more commonly with interstitial lung disease. In patients with ILD, FVC is usually <80% of the predicted value indicating restrictive pathology.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joints for the past week. He has a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. On examination, he has conjunctivitis and the following skin lesions are seen. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute arthritis and conjunctivitis following a recent infection and the given image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica point to the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is non-purulent arthritis following enteric or urogenital infection. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Chlamydia trachomatis.

It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive, involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle.

Extraarticular manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis refers to vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis is commonly seen in young adults. It has a strong association with the HLA-B27 genetic marker. Patients will present with lower lumbar back pain which is insidious in onset. It is accompanied by low-back morning stiffness that improves with activity.

Radiological features include:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity at the distal interphalangeal joint, as shown in the image below.
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation known as whiskering.

 

Option C: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are commonly involved.

questions.text: Which of the following is most consistent with active viral replication in a patient with chronic hepatitis B infection?

choices.text: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgM positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative

questions.solution:
Chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication has the following serological findings: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, and Anti-HBe negative.

After a person is infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serologic marker to increase in level is HBsAg. It becomes detectable in the serum between 1-12 weeks. It becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once the HBsAg becomes undetectable, anti-HBs antibody starts rising in serum and remains detectable indefinitely thereafter. The gap between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is called the window period. If HBsAg persists beyond 6 months, it is likely to be chronic hepatitis B.

HBcAg is located inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. As a result, HBcAg is not commonly detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection since naked core particles are not found in the bloodstream. Conversely, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after the emergence of HBsAg, usually within 1-2 weeks. Anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker useful for the identification of HBV infection during the window period. Initially, the anti-HBc is of IgM variety, but in chronic infections, it is of IgG class.

HBeAg appears shortly after the appearance of HBsAg. Its appearance correlates with high levels of virus replication. Anti-HBe correlates with a period of lower infectivity. In chronic active hepatitis, HBeAg persists and anti-HBe does not appear.

questions.text: On evaluating a patient with polyuria, it was found that his urine osmolality was 220 mOsm/L, and the serum level of vasopressin was low. An MRI brain was done and is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with low urine osmolality and serum vasopressin, with MRI brain showing a bright spot in the posterior pituitary is suggestive of psychogenic polydipsia.

In a patient presenting with polyuria, the first step is to measure urine osmolarity on unrestricted fluid intake. If the urine osmolarity is <300 mOsm/L, diabetes insipidus (DI) is confirmed. The next step is to measure plasma vasopressin. If the circulating levels of vasopressin are elevated, it indicates that DI has occurred because it is not able to act on the kidney — indicating nephrogenic DI. If vasopressin is decreased, the next step is to do an MRI of the brain. A bright spot in the posterior pituitary is present in normal individuals. Its presence in a patient with reduced vasopressin and low urine osmolarity indicates a diagnosis of primary or psychogenic polydipsia. The absence of posterior pituitary bright spot indicates central DI.

An alternative method to differentiate between DI and psychogenic polydipsia is to do a fluid deprivation test when urine osmolarity is found to be low. If fluid restriction results in the concentration of the urine (increase in the urine osmolarity), it indicates that the patient has primary polydipsia. If, however, the urine osmolarity remains unchanged on fluid restriction, diabetes insipidus is confirmed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. She has been trying to conceive for the past two years. Her UPT is negative and she is not on any medications. Serum prolactin is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step for this patient is to measure serum TSH, T3, and T4, because hypothyroidism should be ruled out in any patient with hyperprolactinemia before starting an extensive diagnostic workup.

Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and infertility are the characteristic features of hyperprolactinemia in females. In males, hyperprolactinemia presents with diminished libido, visual loss (due to compression of the optic tract), and infertility. 

In any patient presenting with hyperprolactinemia, the physician must always rule out physiological causes (pregnancy, lactation), hypothyroidism, and a history of use of drugs associated with hyperprolactinemia. Low thyroxine in patients with hypothyroidism causes increased TRH release from the hypothalamus. TRH induces prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary. 

Once these causes have been ruled out, the next step is to do an MRI of the brain to identify a functional pituitary tumor, that is, a prolactinoma. A microadenoma is a pituitary tumor of size < 10 mm. If the size is ≥ 10 mm, it is termed a macroadenoma. Macroadenomas are more likely to cause visual symptoms.

Initial management for both is dopamine agonists, such as cabergoline. It successfully reduces prolactin levels, improves fertility, and causes a shrinkage of the tumor. Bromocriptine is another dopamine agonist used in the management of prolactinoma, especially in pregnant patients. If there is no reduction in the size of the tumors, or there is persistent tumor growth or persistent hyperprolactinemia, surgery is considered.

An elderly patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the hospital with confusion and drowsiness. He had an episode of pneumonia 2 weeks back and his oral intake has reduced significantly since then. Laboratory findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

Blood glucose: 700 mg/dL

Urinalysis: mild ketonuria

Arterial pH: 7.38

Serum bicarbonate: 24 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This diagnosis is  hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). 

HHS is commonly seen in older adults suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus predominantly. Patients can present with the following features:

  • Polyuria
  • Polydipsia
  • confusion,drowsiness
  • Altered sensorium, coma
  • Seizures
  • Severe dehydration
  • concomitant infection, MI, stroke

The following lab values are seen: 

  • Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/dl
  • Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L
  • Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration
  • Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia
  • Normal pH and ketones (Some cases can have mild ketonuria).

The mainstay of management is fluid replacement, IV regular insulin, along with potassium replacement. Heparin can be given prophylactically as volume contraction can increase the risk of venous thrombosis.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is an acute, severe, hyperglycemic disorder, which was considered a hallmark of type 1 diabetes. It can occur in type 2 diabetes as well. Inadequate administration of insulin (especially during times of physiologic stress like infections) may precipitate DKA.

Features of DKA include:

  • Nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain
  • Hypotension and tachycardia
  • Hyperglycemia (350 mg/dl to 500 mg/dl), glycosuria, and ketosis
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient came with complaints of a painful and swollen right knee, and difficulty in walking. After examining the knee joint, aspiration is done. On synovial fluid examination using compensated polarized microscopy, positive birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals are seen. What is the composition of the crystals deposited in this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and synovial fluid analysis showing positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are suggestive of pseudogout. There is the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate in this disorder.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD). It presents with features similar to acute gout and predominantly affects the elderly. This is attributable to the increased levels of inorganic pyrophosphate in diseased or aging cartilage which promotes CPP crystal nucleation and their deposition.

Acute attacks of CPPD present with joint swelling and pain, affecting the knee (most common), wrist, shoulders, elbows, and hands. It also has systemic features of inflammation including fever, chills, and elevated CRP. Chronic CPPD commonly presents as polyarticular arthritis resembling osteoarthritis (pseudo-osteoarthritis). It affects atypical joints such as metacarpophalangeal, wrist, elbow, and ankle joints causing severe damage.

X-ray or ultrasonography of the joint shows chondrocalcinosis, which is punctate or linear radiodense deposits in the joint menisci or articular cartilage. Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage is diagnostic of pseudogout.

The below image shows rhomboid-shaped and positive birefringent calcium pyrophosphate crystals in pseudogout.

Option D: Calcium oxalate crystal deposition occurs in primary oxalosis and secondary to chronic renal disease. The crystals have variable shapes and variable birefringence to polarized light.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient is admitted for acute pancreatitis. He complains of breathlessness and cough 3 days later. He is diagnosed to be in acute respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is not included in the diagnostic criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome?

PaO2- Partial pressure of oxygen

FiO2- Fraction of inspired oxygen
questions.solution:
Unilateral interstitial infiltrates are not included in the diagnostic criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome.

The diagnostic criteria as per Berlin's definition of ARDS is:

  • It develops within 1 week of clinical insult or onset of respiratory symptoms.
  • Chest radiograph shows bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. These opacities are not fully explained by effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules.
  • The pulmonary edema is not due to cardiac failure, or fluid overload.
  • There is impaired oxygenation. The ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) is ≤ 300 mmHg as assessed on 5 cm H2O of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). 

Depending on the value of PaO2/FiO2 (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O) it can be

  • Mild: PaO2/FiO2 is between 300mmHg to 200 mmHg
  • Moderate: PaO2/FiO2 is between 200mmHg to 100 mmHg
  • Severe: PaO2/FiO2 is ≤ 100mmHg

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is the most severe type of acute lung injury characterized by poor oxygenation, pulmonary infiltrates, and acuity of onset. It is associated with capillary endothelial injury and diffuse alveolar damage. Conditions associated with direct lung injury like pneumonia, aspiration of gastric contents, pulmonary contusion, near-drowning, and toxic inhalational injury are associated with ARDS. Systemic conditions causing indirect lung injury and ARDS include sepsis, severe trauma (head injury, burns, multiple bone fractures), multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.

ARDS is characterized by the development of dyspnea, tachypnea, and increased work of breathing. The chest radiograph shows opacities involving most of the bilateral lung fields as shown below.

 

The main treatment strategy which has been shown to reduce mortality in patients is low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Conventional tidal volume ventilation leads to overdistension injury because the lung in ARDS is already consolidated and any attempt to push more air through it will lead to barotrauma. Apart from this, high PEEP, prone position, early neuromuscular blockade, and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may also be useful.

A 52-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. On investigation, serum GGT and ALP levels were found to be elevated with a mild elevation in AST and ALT levels. The histopathological image of her liver biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?

GGT- Gamma glutamyl transferase

AST- Aspartate aminotransferase

choices.text: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with the presence of florid duct lesions on histopathology is indicative of primary biliary cholangitis. The antibodies most likely to be present in PBC are anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA).

Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium-sized bile ducts. It has a strong female preponderance with a median age of 50 years.

The most common symptoms include fatigue that is out of proportion to the severity of the liver disease or the patient's age and pruritus, which is usually most bothersome in the evening. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease, including hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites, and edema are found to be present.

Amond the liver enzymes, GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. The majority of the patients show anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) positive. A liver biopsy shows a florid duct lesion. This occurs due to the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.

Liver transplantation is indicated in patients with decompensated cirrhosis due to PBC. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line drug that helps to slow down the rate of progression of the disease.

Other options:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is a known case of colon cancer. He develops puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urinary protein level was 4 gm/24 h. CT abdomen shows renal vein thrombus. What is the most probable cause behind this nephrotic presentation?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on nephrotic presentation and history of colon cancer associated with thrombotic complication points to membranous glomerulonephritis also known as membranous nephropathy.

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in older adults, with a peak incidence in 30–50 years and a male: female ratio of 2:1. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease. It can be primary (75% of cases) or secondary. Factors that can lead to secondary membranous nephropathy include:

  • Solid malignancies - colon, breast, lung.
  • Infection - Hepatitis B, Syphilis, Malaria, Schistosomiasis
  • Rheumatological disorders - Lupus, IgG4-related disease.

Light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall, due to deposition of immune complexes between the basement membrane and the overlying epithelial cells. Irregular spikes of basement membrane between these deposits are best seen with silver stains. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows diffuse granular deposits containing IgG and C3. Electron microscopy shows electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated with renal vein thrombosis. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

questions.text: A young patient presents with resistant hypertension. CT abdomen is shown below. Which of the following conditions may also be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of resistant hypertension and the CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys point to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). One of the manifestations of ADPKD is in the form of Berry aneurysms.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The patients present with hypertension and flank pain. The cause of the pain is the infection of the renal cysts, hemorrhage, or concomitant stone formation. Gross hematuria can also occur when the cyst ruptures. The most important causes of mortality in patients with ADPKD are cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, and infections of the cyst. The patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by late middle age.

Manifestations of ADPKD in other organs include:

  • Cysts in the liver, pancreas, spleen, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Colonic diverticulae
  • Abdominal wall hernias

The diagnosis is made using typical clinical features, family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, and the presence of multiple, bilateral cysts on imaging. Ultrasound is often used as the first-line investigation. CT and T2 weighted MRI are more sensitive than ultrasound in detecting smaller-sized cysts.

Treatment includes strict control of BP using blockers of RAAS, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers. Tolvaptan (vasopressin antagonist), sirolimus, and everolimus (mTOR pathway inhibitors) have been shown to delay the progression of renal disease. More than half of the patients with ADPKD eventually require renal replacement therapy in the form of hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or renal transplant.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of dyspnea. Examination showed tender hepatomegaly, pedal edema, and jugular venous distension. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur was heard on the left lower sternal border. JVP waveform of the patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's congestive symptoms (hepatomegaly, pedal edema, and jugular venous distension), JVP showing giant a wave, and the presence of diastolic murmur in the tricuspid area — all point to a diagnosis of tricuspid stenosis.

Tricuspid stenosis does not occur as an isolated lesion, and is usually seen in association with mitral stenosis. It generally occurs as a consequence of rheumatic heart disease. Patients present with features of venous congestion, such as hepatomegaly, ascites, and edema. There is jugular venous distension, with giant a waves (due to increased RA pressure to pump the blood through the stenosed valve) and slow y descent (due to obstruction to emptying of the RA due to the stenosed valve).

On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard, appreciated best along the lower left sternal border and xiphisternum. The intensity of the murmur increases on inspiration and decreases during expiration and the Valsalva maneuver due to decreased blood flow across the tricuspid valve.

ECG shows features of right atrial enlargement which includes tall and peaked P waves in lead II and upright P waves in lead V1. Surgical treatment of TS is carried out at the time of MS repair.
