questions.text: A 24-year-old man with breathing difficulty has a flow-volume loop as given below. What is the likely mechanism which can explain the given loop?

choices.text: Variable intrathoracic obstruction due to tracheomalacia
Restriction due to increased lung elastic recoil
Restriction due to chest wall abnormality

questions.solution:
The given flow-volume loop showing a scooped-out pattern suggests obstruction due to airway narrowing such as acute asthma. 

During an episode of acute asthma, there is a narrowing of the small- and medium-sized airways. This occurs due to constriction of the smooth muscles lining the airways, and inflammatory thickening of the walls of the airways. Because of this, there is a decrease in the maximal expiratory flow during the later part of the flow-volume curve. This produces the scooped-out or coved pattern seen in the flow-volume loop shown. This obstruction cannot be overcome by increasing the expiratory effort, but can be reversed by the use of β2 agonist agents. 

A similar pattern is also seen in COPD because of premature airway closure due to the loss of elastic support of the lung parenchyma on the airways (seen in emphysema) and inflammation of the lower airways (seen in chronic bronchitis). Bronchiectasis and bronchiolitis also show a scooped-out expiratory limb on the flow-volume curve.

 

Any restrictive disease will show a reduction in forced vital capacity (FVC). This is characterized by a smaller flow-volume loop than normal. If the restriction is caused by increased lung recoil (option B), such as interstitial lung disease, there will be a reduction in residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC) as well. RV and TLC usually remain normal if the restriction is caused by chest wall problems (option D).

Variable intrathoracic obstruction (option A) produces a flattening of the expiratory limb of the flow-volume loop, while the inspiratory limb remains normal. The pleural pressure is negative relative to the airway pressure during inspiration, which allows air to flow into the lungs normally despite an airway obstruction. However, the pleural pressure becomes positive relative to the airway pressure during expiration, and this worsens the effect of the obstructive lesion in the airways.

questions.text: Which of the following findings of cirrhosis is not due to portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Spider angiomas seen in patients with chronic liver disease are not due to portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension is defined as the elevation of the hepatic venous pressure gradient to >5 mmHg. It occurs due to resistance to blood flow in the liver due to fibrosis and nodules of regenerating parenchyma, and due to increased splanchnic blood flow. The complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, splenomegaly, ascites, and portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Spider angiomas (also known as spider naevus or spider telangiectasias) consist of a central arteriole, about pin-headed in size from which steadily narrowing capillaries radiate like spider legs, as shown below. They are believed to occur due to the altered metabolism of sex steroids. They are not specific to cirrhosis, and can be seen in pregnancy, and otherwise healthy individuals as well (up to 3 small lesions can be considered normal). 

 

Other findings on physical examination that occur due to inadequate hepatic metabolism of sex steroids include:

  • Testicular atrophy, loss of chest hair, and gynecomastia in males
  • Menstrual irregularities in females
  • Decreased libido
  • Palmar erythema, which is a symmetrical, bilateral, non-painful redness of palms due to cutaneous vasodilation. The center of the palm is usually spared.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about lupus nephritis?

choices.text: Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis does not require treatment
Renal biopsy is recommended for every SLE patient with clinical evidence of nephritis
Lupus nephritis progresses to end-stage renal disease if left untreated
Advanced sclerotic lupus nephritis requires aggressive treatment

questions.solution:
Advanced sclerotic lupus nephritis (class VI) does not need any treatment. 

Nephritis is a leading cause of mortality in patients with SLE. Any patient presenting with features of SLE should undergo urine analysis to detect asymptomatic nephritis. If there is clinical evidence of nephritis such as frank hematuria or hypertension, a renal biopsy is recommended. Percutaneous kidney biopsy are generally safe, with the only major risk being that of bleeding in the first 72 hours following biopsy. The patient should be closely observed following a kidney biopsy for any major bleeding episode and anticoagulation should be withheld following a kidney biopsy.

The severity of the injury as seen on kidney biopsy is important for establishing the diagnosis and starting the appropriate treatment. Focal and diffuse lupus nephritis (class III and IV), and membranous lupus nephritis (class V) are treated with aggressive immunosuppression. Treatment is not recommended for minimal mesangial and mesangioproliferative lupus nephritis (classes I and II), and if there is extensive irreversible damage, as in advanced sclerotic lupus nephritis (class VI).

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following nail finding. Which of the following conditions is it likely to be associated with?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows subungual splinter hemorrhages, which are associated with infective endocarditis.

Subungual splinter hemorrhages are identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed. They are one of the vascular manifestations seen in infective endocarditis. They occur due to septic emboli breaking off from the valvular vegetation and blocking the peripheral capillaries.

Other peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous nodules that occur due to dermal infarcts due to septic emboli. They are usually found in the distal part of the fingers and are transient, as shown in the image below.

 

  • Janeway lesions are painless erythematous lesions in the palms, as shown in the image below.
  • Roth spots are retinal hemorrhages with a whitish center.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of blurring of vision of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy demonstrates giant cells. Which of the following medications should she be started on to prevent complete blindness?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from temporal arteritis / giant cell arteritis, and must be started on methylprednisone to protect her vision.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis is an inflammation of predominantly large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have signs of superficial temporal artery inflammation, including erythema, pain on palpation, nodularity, thickening, or reduced pulsation on the affected side. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore, patients with a clinical diagnosis of GCA, especially with headaches or visual symptoms should immediately be started on steroids. If treatment is delayed beyond 48 hours, there may be irreversible damage.

The mainstay of treatment in GCA is steroids. Prednisolone 40-60 mg is given for one month followed by tapering doses. The duration of treatment is approximately 2 years or more. Methylprednisolone 1000 mg for 3 days should be given to patients presenting with visual symptoms.

Aspirin reduces the occurrence of visual loss and can be given in addition to steroids. Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig). Both these drugs are used adjunctively to steroid therapy.

questions.text: The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis is:

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. 

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which acidosis occurs because of the inability of the tubules of the kidney to perform normal functions required to maintain acid-base balance. In this disorder, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is relatively well-preserved.

The defect is either inability to excrete hydrogen ions (inadequate generation of new bicarbonate ions) or inadequate reabsorption of bicarbonate ions. 

Types of RTA:

  • Type I - distal RTA or classical RTA is characterised by the inability to excrete H+ ions by the distal nephron. The urinary pH is >5.5, as the urine cannot be fully acidified, despite systemic acidosis. 
  • Type II - proximal RTA is characterised by the inability to reabsorb filtered bicarbonate by the proximal tubule.
  • Type III - mixed type, similar to both type I and II.
  • Type IV - is the most common type of RTA in clinical practice. This is a disorder of hyperkalemia, that occurs due to decreased aldosterone, which inhibits ammonium production.

The anion gap is the difference between readily measured anions and cations. The normal anion gap is 12 ± 4 mEq/L. The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types of RTA is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal. This kind of metabolic abnormality is also seen in gastrointestinal losses.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability. He has also been treated twice for urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. An x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the skull radiograph showing punched-out lesions suggest multiple myeloma. Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, and elevated ESR are the laboratory parameters consistent with a diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increased osteoclast activity and accelerated bone destruction. Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic and normochromic anemia
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes
  • Elevated ESR
  • Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein
  • Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include: 

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%
    • Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with an altered mental status, flank pain, and polyuria. Laboratory investigations reveal hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria. He has a history of lung cancer, for which he underwent chemotherapy a few months back.  What is the next line of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy, a paraneoplastic syndrome occurring probably due to underlying lung cancer. The next line of management in this patient is the administration of intravenous saline.

Hypercalcemia of malignancy results from the ectopic production of PTH-related peptide (PTHrP). PTHrP is structurally similar to PTH and binds to the same receptors and has the same downstream actions. This is seen in squamous cell carcinomas of head and neck, lungs, and skin. Another mechanism that may be involved is the excess production of 1,25-hihydroxycholecalciferol, otherwise known as calcitriol. 
 
Patients are usually found to have hypercalcemia on routine laboratory tests. Calcium levels are markedly elevated, often >14 mg/dL. Patients may present with altered mental status, polyuria, dehydration, and renal stones. ECG shows shortened ST segment and QT interval. 

Laboratory investigations reveal high serum calcium levels, hypercalciuria, hypophosphatemia, and metabolic alkalosis. PTH measurement is useful in excluding hyperparathyroidism. PTH is suppressed in cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy, while it is elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Initial management is by rehydration with intravenous normal saline to dilute serum calcium levels. Along with this, subcutaneous calcitonin is also administered, to promote renal excretion of calcium and prevent further bone resorption. Intravenous bisphosphonates such as zoledronate and pamidronate (option C) reduce serum calcium levels over the next 1–2 days and provide a more sustained effect.

Forced diuresis with loop diuretics (option A) can be used in life-threatening hypercalcemia only after complete rehydration and with careful monitoring of fluid balance. Hemodialysis (option D) is considered in patients with renal insufficiency or heart failure, in whom hydration cannot be given without the risk of worsening of fluid status. Denosumab is used in patients with refractory hypercalcemia despite bisphosphonate therapy or if there is any contraindication to bisphosphonates.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of pain and early morning stiffness in the lower back. The following test was done. In which disease is the following test done?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the modified Schober test. It is done to measure lumbar spine flexion in ankylosing spondylitis.

In this test, the patient stands erect with the heels together, and two points are marked on the spine, as shown in the illustration below: one at the level of the lumbosacral junction (a horizontal line between the two posterosuperior iliac spines) and one 10 cm above this level. The patient is then asked to bend forward, and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by ≥ 2 cm.

HLA-B27 is strongly linked to AS and it plays a direct role in the pathogenesis of the disease. The clinical features of AS first appear during late adolescence and early adulthood. The patients complain of early morning pain and stiffness in the lower back. The condition improves with activity and returns with inactivity. As the disease progresses, the pain becomes bilateral and persistent. 

On examination, there is restriction of all the movements of the lumbar spine (anterior and lateral flexion, and extension). Other changes which are seen in the spine include obliteration of the lumbar lordosis, accentuated thoracic kyphosis, and restriction of the chest expansion. In advanced spinal disease, there is a high risk of spinal fracture (most often in the cervical region) due to osteoporosis and the spine being rigid. Such a fracture is mostly associated with spinal cord injury.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the ER with weakness in both legs since yesterday. The weakness has progressed to his arms now and he is having difficulty in breathing. He had an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis in all four limbs and arreflexia. CSF examination shows elevated protein levels but normal cell count. What is the further management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of ascending, flaccid type of paralysis following an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago, and CSF examination showing increased protein with normal cell count, point to a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). 

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The possible antecedent events include respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. The implicated organisms include Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, and Mycoplasma pneumonia.

The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Almost one-third of the patients require mechanical ventilation due to weakness of the respiratory muscles. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Sensations carried by large myelinated fibers like deep tendon reflexes and proprioception are also affected. Pain and temperature sensations are relatively preserved. Autonomic involvement usually presents with loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuations in blood pressure and postural hypotension. Fever and constitutional symptoms are absent at the onset of the weakness. Similarly, bladder dysfunction occurs only in severe GBS and is transient. Prominent bladder dysfunction occurring early in the disease course goes against the diagnosis of GBS. 

The patient is likely to have clinical worsening during the first four weeks following the onset of weakness. After this, there's a plateauing of the symptoms and any further deterioration is unlikely.

The treatment for GBS should be initiated as early as possible. High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis can be used for the treatment. A sequential combination of the two has not been found to be more effective than either of them alone. Corticosteroids (option A) are not effective in the treatment of GBS.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: Lab investigations of a patient show low TSH, low T3, and low T4. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and TSH are low in this patient. The most likely cause for this secondary hypothyroidism. 

If the thyroid gland is not producing enough T3 and T4, ideally the thyrotrophs in the anterior pituitary should produce more TSH to cause more downstream stimulation of the thyroid gland. Since this is not happening in this case and TSH is low despite T3 and T4 being low, the problem is likely to be in the central axis involving the pituitary gland or the hypothalamus. This is referred to as secondary hypothyroidism.
